translated: Birth Stories🔽The Thirteen Group🔽The Chapter on Mangoes
The Birth Story of the Swift Swan
“Swan, land right here,
I like to see you.
You have come as a lord,
tell me what you want.”
“Some people are dear because of hearing about them,

analyzed: disvā pana ekassa viya iti chandaḥ
translated: but when one sees them, one’s desire fades.

original: Disvā ca sutvā ca piyā bhavanti,
analyzed: disvā ca sutvā ca piyāḥ bhavanti
translated: Some people are dear because of seeing and hearing about them.
Are you dear to me because of seeing you?
You are dear to me because of hearing about you,
and even more so because of seeing you.
In this way, you are dear to see for me,
so stay with me, swan.”
“We would live in your house,
always honored and respected.
But if you were to make a mistake,
‘Cook the king of swans for me.’”
“Shame on that drinking of alcohol,
which is dearer to me than you.
And I do not drink alcohol,
as long as you are in my house.”
“The howls of jackals
and the cries of birds are well known.
But, King, the cries of humans
are even more difficult to know than that.
Even if a person thinks
‘this one is a relative, a friend, or a companion,’
One who was previously happy,
later becomes unhappy.

analyzed: yasmin manaḥ nivisati  avidūre saha api saḥ
translated: Where the mind becomes fixed,🔽even if far away, it is near;
For even if near, it is far,
where the mind does not become fixed.

analyzed: antar pi saḥ hoti pasanna cittaḥ
translated: Even within, one’s mind is serene,
with a serene mind beyond the ocean;

analyzed: antar api saḥ hoti paduṭṭha cittaḥ
translated: Even within, one’s mind is corrupted,

analyzed: pāram samuddassa paduṭṭha cittaḥ  sa vasantā vivasanti
translated: with a corrupted mind beyond the ocean.🔽Those who dwell in the directions,
shine forth, O Lord of Chariots;
The peaceful ones dwell together,
with a mind to increase the kingdom.
By dwelling too long,
one becomes dear, then not dear;
I invite you, we will go,
before we become not dear to each other.”

analyzed: evañce yācamānāna  añjalim na avabujjhasi  paricārakānam sata
translated: “If, when asked in this way,🔽you do not understand the outstretched hands;🔽You do not heed the words
of the many who serve you;
Thus we invite you,
make another turn.”
“If, while we dwell thus,
there will be no obstacle;
For you, great king,
and for me, O Enhancer of the Kingdom;
Perhaps we may see
the passing of days and nights.”
The Birth Story of the Swift Geese is the third.
